title: Stephen's Defense and Martyrdom
shortSummary: Acts Chapter 7 records Stephen’s powerful defense before the Sanhedrin, recounting Israel’s history from Abraham to Moses and highlighting their continual rejection of God’s messengers. His bold proclamation exposes the Jewish leaders’ resistance to the Holy Spirit, culminating in his martyrdom, the first recorded Christian martyr.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - Early Church in Jerusalem, shortly after Pentecost

keyCharacters.name: Stephen
keyCharacters.description: A deacon in the early church who boldly defends the Christian faith before the Jewish council and becomes the first Christian martyr.

keyCharacters.name: High Priest
keyCharacters.description: The Jewish religious leader who questions Stephen at the beginning of his defense.

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch to whom God first appeared and made promises, serving as the starting point of Stephen’s historical recount.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The deliverer of Israel from Egypt, whose life and mission Stephen highlights as a foreshadowing of Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: A young man present at Stephen’s stoning who later becomes the Apostle Paul.

definitions.definition: The chief religious leader of the Jewish people, responsible for temple worship and leading the Sanhedrin.
A covenant sign given to Abraham and his descendants, symbolizing their special relationship with God.
The third Person of the Trinity, God’s Spirit who empowers, convicts, and guides believers.
One who suffers death because of their faith in Jesus Christ.
The portable sanctuary where God’s presence dwelt among the Israelites during their wilderness journey.

outline.heading: Stephen’s Historical Defense: From Abraham to Joseph
outline.description: Stephen begins by recounting God’s call to Abraham and the patriarchs, emphasizing God’s promises and providence despite their hardships and displacement.

outline.heading: Israel’s Oppression and Moses’ Early Life
outline.description: Stephen describes Israel’s growth in Egypt, the rise of a hostile king, and the birth and early life of Moses, setting the stage for God’s deliverance.

outline.heading: God’s Call to Moses and Israel’s Rejection
outline.description: Stephen narrates Moses’ encounter with God at the burning bush, his mission to deliver Israel, and Israel’s continued rebellion including idolatry and rejection of God’s law.

outline.heading: The Tabernacle and God’s True Dwelling
outline.description: Stephen explains the significance of the tabernacle and Solomon’s temple, emphasizing that God’s presence is not confined to man-made structures.

outline.heading: Stephen’s Rebuke and Martyrdom
outline.description: Stephen confronts the Jewish leaders for resisting the Holy Spirit and persecuting the prophets, sees a vision of Jesus, and is stoned to death, praying for his persecutors.

application: Stand firm in your faith and boldly proclaim the gospel, even in the face of opposition or persecution.
Remember God’s faithfulness throughout history and trust His promises, especially when facing trials or uncertainty.
Avoid resisting the Holy Spirit’s work in your life; instead, be obedient and receptive to His guidance.
Pray for those who oppose or persecute you, following Stephen’s example of forgiveness and love.

keyVerses.text: But he, being full of the Holy Ghost, looked up stedfastly into heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing on the right hand of God,
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Stephen’s Spirit-filled vision affirming Jesus’ divine authority and presence at God’s right hand.

keyVerses.text: Ye stiffnecked and uncircumcised in heart and ears, ye do always resist the Holy Ghost: as your fathers did, so do ye.
keyVerses.significance: Stephen’s rebuke exposes the hardness of heart and resistance to God’s Spirit, a warning against unbelief and rebellion.

keyVerses.text: And they stoned Stephen, calling upon God, and saying, Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.
keyVerses.significance: Stephen’s prayer in martyrdom exemplifies faith and surrender to Jesus, trusting Him even in death.

keyVerses.text: This is that Moses, which said unto the children of Israel, A prophet shall the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me; him shall ye hear.
keyVerses.significance: Stephen points to the promised prophet, Jesus Christ, whom the people were to hear, connecting the Old Testament promise to the gospel.
